moves.2. exd5: Accepted, which is best for white but much more tactic and complicated to play...
moves.2... Nf6: This is recommended instead of Qxd4, which leads to a "hanging queen" that will be easily targeted for white while developing. That's true. I still hold some hopes about the Qa5 or Qe4+ moves, but if more experienced players say they are bad... they probably are. This one seems just to gambit a pawn, because white can assure it by f4.
moves.3. Bc4: If 13. f4 instead, black is known to have enough compensation after e6, 14. dxe6, Bxe6, followed by Bb4, Ne4 etc. White will be forced to play defensively. I expected 14. Nc3 or 14. Nf3, which allow e6 (the so-called Icelandic Gambit), a line I am experiencing with. BUT I seldom or never faced this natural move. OF course, I can just take the pawn. But this gets me out of my "confort line".
moves.3... Nxd5 4. Nf3: Incredible, but it was the first time I faced this situation. Could I have simply played Nb6? NO!, because of Bxf7+, KxB, Ne4+, with a very strong attack for the piece (still better that what came later). The right move here is Bg4 (now!), prepared to exchange it, or just e6 - provided black manages to develop his lsb on b7 or a6.
moves.4... Nf4: ?! Counterintuitive, antideveloping, etc. I just thought that normally this move can't be played because white's dsb guards f4, and the white K is castled... but not now. Of course, this move leaves white Bxf7+, KxB, Ne5+... winning, if I remember well some good games from great players in similar positions.
moves.5. O-O: White goes for the easy way. I have to stop WN jump, and I don't like f6 at all. At the same time, I was considering what would be needed to make of h3 a sac point, either for N or B. When returning into the game
moves.5... Bg4: ?? Now I can clearly see it, as I did when analyzing the position. Then, I re-opened the board and played mechanically. After the move, I realized what had I done, and... paid for the consecuences.
moves.6. Bxf7+: By the B move I just offered white another piece to munch after the N check. Kd7 is useless too because of Ne5+...
moves.6... Kxf7 7. Ne5+ Kg8: Could Ke8 or Kf6 be better?
moves.8. Qxg4: The problem for black is to prevent Qe6#... and the N is hanging!
moves.8... Qd4: Fearing f3, planning Nh6+. Against any answer, QxN.
moves.9. Qf5: Threatening the N and Qf7#, but allowing Ne2+. But this check is useless. Let's make room for my K.
moves.10. Nc3: Passive, but in this situation, for white almost any move is good! This forbids Ne2+, but for black there are more urgent issues to assess. I would have gone f3 instead, followed by N4. True is that after Ne2+, Kh1, NxB, RxN, White loses his dsb but still has a better position.
moves.10... e6: Now that my K has an escape square, I can play this tricky move. It accomplishes a lot of things: forces white into react instead of attacking (Qf7+, Kh7, and...?). Opens the way for the dsb. Cuts white's support of d7 (so my N can came out). About countermoves: if Nb5, Qb6, QxN, QxN.
moves.11... Kh7 12. d3: Nf3 could go now e4-f6#. I thought that the "natural" Nd5 just loses to Ng6 or Qxe6, so I had to find something else:
moves.12... Bd6: The plan is to recover my N with his, unravel a little my pieces, and force white away. If 13. Be3, QxN.
moves.13... Rf8: ?? I thought I was making the most of my poor forces, and dreamed to get a powerful counterattack. This was the second tactic I missed.
moves.14... Kh8 15. Nf7+: ! Not only I won't recover the piece, but I will have to lose the exchange in order to survive (Kg8, Nxh6+, and white wins as he wants).
moves.15... Rxf7 16. Bxd6: ! Leaving me without my best placed piece, and there is nothing I can do to recover my minor piece dued, since Rd7 doesn't save the R against Qe8+... QxR.
moves.16... Rxf2: ...but can I still grab a pawn and get an interesting pin.
moves.17. Rxf2: Now I should have recovered the piece, but if I do cxB (possible since Rf2 is pinned), but white will take e6, and I will have at most a losing endgame.
moves.17... Nc6: Better to cover the 8th rank and get two pieces more into the action!
moves.18... e5: Blocking the B's action, and "defending" my hanging e6 pawn.
moves.19. Qe4: Trying to provoke the Q''s exchange, after which I'm lost.
moves.19... Qc5: Still defending e5, but fearing Na5. Could I released white from the pin?
moves.20. Raf1: I still have Rf1 here,m making the most of my weak position.
moves.20... b5: ?? I just thought to prevent Na5. White's threats are too much to cover them all. All I can do is making his win a little harder. If 28... Rf1, 29. Na5 and I lose more material.
moves.21. Kh1: Released the pin, I am at a very short distance from Rf8+ and mate.
moves.21... Rg8: Making things harder for white. I can't move the N or Bxe4. Maybe Re8 could have been better.
moves.22. Rf2f5: I can admit my mistake, and go Re8, but again, it seems only a meaningless resistance, after the material disadvantage.
moves.22... Nd4: ? Using my last piece, but what else?
moves.23. Bxe5: ! The B in e5 whorts more than the exchange. Nxc2 was useless, so...
moves.27... Rf8: The last useless hop: Ng6? QxN, QxQ, Rf1#. But my opponent is not so naive.
moves.28. h3: I wonder (but I'll let my opponent to find out) a better move for white. This is enough...
moves.29. Ng6+ Kg8: Incredibly enough, it doesn't came to the eye a mate combination for white. Is there one?
moves.30. g4: This is a three-move attack: g5, gxh6 are two tempoes, so...
moves.30... Qxa2: Now I am the one threating mate. Unless white finds a mating seguence right now. An he does!
moves.31. Qa8+ Kh7 32. Rxh6+: I saw some lines after KxR, and I found mate. The other option leads to it straight forward.
moves.32... gxh6 33. Qh8+ Kxg6 34. Qg8+ Rg7 35: Not a game to be proud of. My head is not at chess when worrying how to get to pay the rent. Still, I hope you had some good laughts reviewing it. A good deserved victory for my opponent. Good for him!
